comments.message: As a use of cutting edge technology (bio-tech), I find this idea quite compelling. I have some key questions (some of which may have already occurred to you):1] What experiments (using this tech or similar tech) have been conducted to date? Also: controlling the pore size/diameter would seem to be crucial -- can uniform and exact nano-pore size be assured/controlled? Also: Molybdenum is crucial for key cellular (synthesis) processes, but too much can disrupt cells...How can non-contamination (of a healthcare provider) by such a nano-material (and its constituent nano-particles) be assured (i.e., the safety of material)?2] Manufacturing/fabricating nano-materials can be http://expensive...is there an existing estimate of the cost per face mask or 'suit'? Is there an estimate of cost (and cost reduction per unit) after scaling up the fabrication process? How easily/readily scalable is the material design?3] Molybdenum is a relatively rare metal -- How is this metal element to be sourced? (supplied?)

Dear Mr. Ricciardi,Thank you very much for your questions. Very much appreciated. I am interested to find a cheap pores material, such as poly lactic acid (PLA) for example ($1 square meter). The pores diameter can be sized according to the concentration of both  poly lactic and gamma glutamic acid (which gives the hydrophylicity of PLA) in water.  Further the resulted pores  are filled instead of water, with  high concentration of sodium or potassium chloride which result into an osmotic shock for the virus capsid, expelling the virus RNA. the end codon of RNA  can be blocked by the acids I mentioned in the written idea, thus stopping the protein translation and finally protein synthesis.  Everything at this stage is based on a very comprehensive literature search.  The material is safe for the healthcare workers.  I never said anything about molybdenum. I uploaded a nice picture from a website and it was my obligation to wrote the website from where this picture was obtained.Thank you again for the inquiry. I actually intended today to explain more about the ebola killing  process at the spot.
Ok, yes, I referenced Mo based on the image caption.I await further explication of the details.
What details are you more interested in? Please let me know.

Well, further explication/clarification of the actual mechanism(s) involved here:"The pores will be covalently bound to 3 methyl-antranilic acid or indol 3 -propionic acid, which inhibit the growth of  several viruses by inhibiting tryptophanase, the enzyme necessary for tryptophan synthesis. Further, tryptophanase may activate the stop codon of Ebola, UGA, thus stopping protein translation of Ebola. Consequently, an easier neutralization of the deadly virus may be possible."If the acid-based coating inhibits tryptophanase AND tryptophanase may activate the viral stop codon...how will inhibiting this enzyme allow it to also activate (if that is what it does) the viral stop codon (and thus neutralize the virus)? It would seem that these two processes are opposed to each other, or am I missing something?How does the coating (its constituent chemical) get past the virus glyco protein  shell so as to inhibit (switch off) the gene that codes for tryptophanase? thanks, M. R.

Thank you for your comments. The high concentration of salt destroys the capsid, due to osmotic stress releasing Ebola RNA. Further 3 methyl antranilic  acid inhibits tryptophanase. This is an enzyme which reversible hydrolyses tryptophan to indole, pyruvate and ammonia. It was shown in the literature that expression of tryptophanase induced elevated levels of tryptophan http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8501042. Further Tryptophan induction prevents Rho factor-dependent termination of protein translation. In another words tryptophan deficiency may accelerate the stop codon, thus stopping the protein translation and finally protein synthesis. I also will upload an article about osmotic stress and the releasing of nucleic acids from virus capsids.

Thanks...that was a very concise and helpful explanation. I can see now how approach just might work. The way I see it, your tech-wear is a one-two punch to the virus...I look foward to reading the article and learning more about the role of Rho-factor (a translation factor?) in viral genomics. Than k you.
Thank you so very much for your reply. I added you to the team if agree.

description:
I think of a cheap nanopores coating material in which the pores are filled with a high salt concentration which produce osmotic stress of capsid removing the infectious Ebola's RNA.
The pores will be covalently bound to 3 methyl-antranilic acid or indol 3 -propionic acid, which inhibit the growth of  several viruses by inhibiting tryptophanase, the enzyme necessary for tryptophan synthesis. Further, tryptophanase may activate the stop codon of Ebola, UGA, thus stopping protein translation of Ebola. Consequently, an easier neutralization of the deadly virus may be possible. The coating material will be placed around the face, neck, hands and feet.  The protection material will be used at all time until leaving the facility. Because the coated material safety equipment supposes to neutralize any outbreak of Ebola I assume the equipment can be reused after a pertinent checkup using different techniques such as UV rays. The coating material can be also used on the environment where an Ebola patient is placed.
This is a rather simple technique to knockout the RNA protein translation of Ebola.
The picture showed only an example of a nanopore material used for other purposes from Urbana University http://news.illinois.edu/news/14/0813nanopores_NarayanaAluru.html. We are not interested to pursue their idea.
Finally, I have to state that any financial effort should be taken to assure that this outbreak will never happen again.
summary: This is about protection of the people caring for Ebola patients. The clothes and the  face mask , will be coated with  nanopores material, which in certain conditions, will  specifically absorb Ebola RNA. The pores containing a certain inhibitor of tryptophanase may inhibit the protein translation of Ebola, thus neutralizing the deadly virus.  The coating material can be used also for the environment, where the Ebola patients are treated. It may sound a little expensive but the benefit of the procedure may be huge.
title: A Good Way of Preventing Is The Only Way Of Inhibiting A Deadly Disease !
